list.head:
FROM THE WALTER REED COLLECTION OF DR. PHILIP HENCH
WALTER REED CASE
list.item: Showing (1) Walter Reed's birthplace, before and after restoration.

(2) Paper cutter presented to Mrs. Walter Reed, made from the
doorsill of Walter Reed's birthplace.

Unpublished photo of Walter Reed en route to Cuba to do the
yellow fever work, presented to Dr. Hench by Mrs. Reed.

(4) Fever chart of J. R. Kissinger (his was the first successful
case of completely controlled experimental yellow fever) and
Reed's letter to his wife, Dec. 9, 1900, about this case.

(5) Fever chart of John Moran, later medical student at the Uni-
versity of Virginia. This was the special yellow fever ex-
periment carried out in Building No. 2, in which infection
was accomplished in a screened area, as described in Reed's
letter of Dec. 25/6th to his wife.

(6) The oft quoted New Year's letter in which Reed in a moment of
exaltation and thankfulness wrote to his wife of his success.

(7) The preliminary published note on the result of the yellow
fever experiments. This is the copy that belonged to Mrs.
Lazear's mother, Mrs. C. C. Sweitzer. Also shown is the copy
of the reprint of the same article that belonged to Dr. Lazear's
widow.

list.head: WALTER REED MEMENTOS
list.item: (1) Original diploma of Walter Reed from the University of Virginia.
(2) The original of the Well-known photo of Reed.
(3) Shoulder strap worn by Walter Reed when he was a captain.

(4) Commemorative stamps and postmarks honoring Finlay, Reed,
and Gorgas, “conquerors of yellow fever”.

(5) Special Congressional medal awarded to Walter Reed and his
twenty-one associates in the experiments. This is Walter
Reed's own medal.

(6) Honorary degree of LL.D. presented to Walter Reed by the
University of Michigan.
(7) Photostats of other Walter Reed Diplomas.

(8) Walter Reed medal awarded by the American Society of Tropical
Medicine.

div1.p:
Major Jefferson Randolph Kean, University of Virginia alumnus,
was Walter Reed's right hand man during the experiments, and served
Reed as disbursing officer, taking care of the expenses on the ex-
perimental camp, Camp Lazear.

list.item: (1) Kean's disbursing check book.

(2) Photo of the day book of Dr. Rojas from whom Walter Reed
rented Camp Lazear.
(3) Photo taken in Major Kean's office, Quemados, Cuba, 1900.

(4) Pictures of Camp Lazear. On the right are shown Buildings 1
and 2.

(5) Staff of the Station Hospital, Camp Columbia, Cuba, 1900. In
this group are shown many of the volunteers for Walter Reed's
experiments, including Dr. Robert P. Cooke, a University of
Virginia medical school graduate, who underwent experiments
in Building No. 1, which showed that filth and personal ef-
fects were not the medium of communicating yellow fever.

list.head: LAZEAR CASE
list.item:
(1) Microscope used by Lazear in hunting for the possible agent
of yellow fever in the body of the mosquito. (Note Lazear's
name in the microscope box.)

(2) Photo from Lazear's lab notebook showing Lazear's early at-
tempts to relate mosquitoes to yellow fever.

(3) Original fever chart of Dr. James Carroll, member of the
Commission, who allowed Lazear to inoculate him with an in-
fected mosquito and developed the first experimental case
in yellow fever history.

(4) Original fever chart of Lazear's secret “Case XY” (Private
William H. Dean). It was this case that convinced Walter
Reed that the yellow fever commission was on the right track.
(5) Lazear's own fever chart. Note the record of his death.

(6) Three fragments of letters from Dr. Lazear to his wife, show-
ing that he anticipated the other members of the Commission
in his acceptance of the Finlay theory of the relation of the
mosquito to yellow fever. Note particularly the letter of
September 8th, which mentions his secret experiments not known
even to Walter Reed, who had been recalled to Washington.
(7) Memorial statue to Lazear in Havana.

(8) Telegram to Mrs. Lazear from Major Jefferson R. Kean, University
of Virginia medical school graduate, announcing Dr. Lazear's death.
(9) Tribute of Dr. Agramonte to Dr. Lazear.

list.head: MORAN CASE
list.item:
(1) Photostatic copy of notes by Walter Reed on John J. Moran's
case.

(2) Photo showing John Moran and Dr. Hench shortly after their
rediscovery of the lost Camp Lazear and Building No. 1.
